Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Rapid Magma Ascent Recorded in Volatile Diffusion Profiles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid Magma Ascent Recorded in Volatile Diffusion Profiles

What makes some eruptions more explosive than others? This fundamental questions is still largely unanswered, even after a given eruption has occurred. Theories link eruptive vigor to the amount of gas and stiffness of the magma, but magmas that have similar stiffness and gas-forming species can still erupt in a wide range of styles, some highly explosive, some quiescent. This project explores another fundamental parameter ? the rate at which magma rises in the volcanic conduit prior to eruption. The magma ascent rate will affect eruptive volume and vigor and also how bubbles form, grow and coalesce. In general, slow magma rise leads to more efficient bubble separation and less explosive eruption. This project aims to test the control of magma rise speed by extracting timescale information from erupted crystals and glass for several eruptions that span a range of exlosive magnitudes.

This project will take advantage of new developments in using the zonation of volatile species in glass and crystals to obtain diffusive timescales that reflect ascent on the order of minutes to days prior to eruption. Four different chronometers will be used: 1) multi-species volatile diffusion through melt embayments, 2) water loss through olivine from melt inclusions of different sizes, 3) water zonation in olivine and clinopyroxene, and 4) zonation inside melt inclusions. Data will be obtained that derive from different microbeam techniques (NanoSIMS, FTIR, electron probe, laser ablation ICPMS) that record chemical zonation at the resolution of 5-25 microns. The proposed targets are a pair of well-documented eruptions from each of three volcanoes: Etna (2001 and 3930BP), Cerro Negro (1992 and 1995) and Paricutin (1943 and 1948), which span the range in mass eruption rates that characterize the transition from strombolian to subplinian styles. The eruptions targeted are specifically designed to test ideas as to the relationship between ascent rate and eruption rate in hydrous mafic magmas, among the most common but least well understood eruptions. This project will support a Ph.D. student and two high school interns from the Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics, a public high school comprised largely of minority students from lower socioeconomic groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What makes some eruptions more explosive than others? This fundamental questions is still largely unanswered, even after a given eruption has occurred. Theories link eruptive vigor to the amount of gas and stiffness of the magma, but magmas that have similar stiffness and gas-forming species can still erupt in a wide range of styles, some highly explosive, some quiescent. This project explored another fundamental parameter – the rate at which magma rises and so decompresses in the volcanic conduit prior to eruption. The magma ascent rate will affect eruptive volume and vigor and also how bubbles form, grow and coalesce. In general, slow magma rise leads to more efficient bubble separation and less explosive eruption. Despite the clear physical link and fundamental importance, very few estimates of ascent or decompression rate exist for any eruption, and several that do exist yield conflicting results. This project aims to test the control of magma rise speed by extracting timescale information from erupted crystals and glass for several eruptions that span a range of explosive intensities.   

This project focused on three volcanic systems: Cerro Negro in Nicaragua, Mt Etna in Sicily, Italy, and Fuego in Guatemala. The first effort was on the 1992 and 1995 eruptions of Cerro Negro which involved identical magma that yet spanned over an order of magnitude in eruptive intensity. Graduate student Anna Barth carried out field work in Nicaragua to sample the two eruptions, and then picked from the volcanic material dozens of tiny olivine crystals that contained microscopic inclusion of trapped magmatic liquid, now quenched to glass. Barth used the ionprobe and nanoSIMS, with collaborator Erik Hauri, at the Carnegie Institution of Washington to measure the H2O and CO2 content of these glass inclusions. She found a relationship between the extent of water loss and the size of the inclusions, which enabled her to calculate the decompression rate for the two eruptions. She found the weaker 1995 eruption ascended and decompressed on average an order of magnitude more slowly that the 1992 eruption, which had the same effect as slowly unscrewing a soda cap – to deflate the eruption. Barth quantified the rate (hours to days) by conducting her own water diffusion experiments, and her own numerical calculations of the diffusion timescales that best fit the natural data. The result is the first study to demonstrate the importance of decompression rate in controlling the intensity of strombolian eruptions and the importance of timescales of hours to days prior to eruptions.

Barth and collaborators also carried out field work on Mt. Etna to sample a range of eruptions of different vigor. Barth focused on the 3930 BP “Fall Stratified” eruption, several orders of magnitude more explosive than the Cerro Negro eruptions. Assisted with summer intern Dylan Bogoevski, she found melt inclusions in very primitive crystals, likely derived directly from the mantle, that contain among the highest CO2 contents yet reported for an explosive volcano. These results point to the possible role of CO2 in driving rapid decompression.

Volcan Fuego in Guatemala erupted in June of 2018, in the middle of this project, and offered an opportunity to test the decompression rate hypothesis by means of contrast to the more violent 1974 eruption of Fuego that had already been extensively studied.  We obtained ash samples collected by Guatemalan collaborators off rooftops kilometers away from the eruption, derived from the 15 km ash plume. Here the project attracted an undergraduate Sarah Shi who made this project her senior thesis. She found that the magma from the 2018 eruption lost half of its H2O due to stalling in the shallow plumbing system prior to eruption, and so had less volatile fuel for eruption than in 1974.  

  Anna Barth will defend her Columbia University PhD thesis in Spring 2021 and then start a postdoctoral project at the University of Oregon. Sarah Shi graduated with a Columbia B.A. and will start graduate school at the University of Cambridge in Spring 2021. Dylan Bogoevski successfully defended his MGeol at St. Andrews University, and is now employed in a mineral resource company in Western Australia. Prof. Terry Plank gave almost 30 departmental, keynote or public lectures to diverse audiences over the course of this project, including to over 750 high school students, on the topic of how magma ascent rate drives eruptive rigor, based on the outcomes of this project.
